citation.article-title: Legionella wadsworthii species nova: a cause of human pneumonia.

p.s: Description of Legionella wadsworthii sp. nov.

Legionella wadsworthii (wads'.wor.thi.i, M.L. gen. n. wadsworthii of VA Wadsworth Medical Center, named after James Wadsworth, and the location where the patient was hospitalized and the bacterium was isolated)
Wadsworth isolate 81-716A is clearly a new species of Legionella.
The isolate shares with all other recognized Legionella species a growth requirement for L-cysteine and a relatively large content of branched chain fatty acids.
The cellular fatty acid composition of Wadsworth 81-716A is essentially identical to that found for L. jordanis, L. bozemanii, L. dumoffii, and L. gormanii (8, 19).
The isolare differs from the cellular fatty acids found in L. micdadei only by the absence of anteiso-17:1 fatty acied, which appears to be unique to L. micdadei.
The fatty acid composition differs quantitatively from that found with L. pneumophila and L. longbeachae, which contain i-16:0 as the major fatty acid.
The new isolate shares only with L. micdadei an inability to produce browning on L-tyrosine supplemented media (8).
All recognized Legionella species are motile, with a single polar flagellum, as is Wadsworth 81-716A (1-8).
The new isolate shared many other phenotypic characteristics with the described Legionella species.
Phenotypically, this organism closely resembles other Legionella species, with the major exception of nonreactivity with direct fluorescent antibody reagents directed against the other species.
This is not unusual for a new species of Legionella, because the only known major cross-reaction between species is that seen with L. bozemanii and L. jordanis (8).
The DNA-relatedness measurements show that Wadsworth 81-716A is unique when compared to other recognized Legionella species.

However, the phenotypic similarities with other Legionella species, and DNA relative binding ratios in the range of 22% to 30% at 60Â°C for some of the Legionella species argue for inclusion of this isolate in the family Legionellaceae and in the genus Legionella.
The isolate's guanine-plus-cytosine content of the 42 moles % is consistent with the DNA base ratios of other Legionella species.

As discussed in other papers, the decision to place new species in the family Legionellaceae and in the genus Legionella is an arbitrary one because of the lack of agreement about the degree of DNA relatedness needed for such classifications.

However, because all these species share very similar guanine-plus-cytosine contents, phenotypic characteristics, and clinical significance, it appears logical to group them in the sam genus and family (7, 8).
